resources.string: Introduction

\tThe %1$s application was originally designed to help decode the 340-character Zodiac cryptogram but now it also provides an ability to create custom ciphers and decode ciphers created by other users.
Decoding

\tTo substitute a letter for a symbol tap on the symbol and type the letter in the dialog. The symbol will be then automatically replaced with the specified letter in every place it is located in.\n\tYou can change the color of the letters in %1$s.

Click the %1$s button with the ribbon icon to remember the binding, i.e. the correspondence between symbols in the cipher and letters, and create a bookmark. To create a named bookmark, long-press the icon. You can change default names of bookmarks in %2$s.
	You can navigate through the bookmarks on the sliding menu.
	To get back to the last bookmark, click %3$s.
	To remove all the letters and start from the beginning, click %4$s.

Click %1$s to show the search dialog.
	Searching words means finding bindings that make the cipher contain these words.
	There are following search parameters:
	%2$s - the results must not contradict the current symbol substitution.
	%3$s - different symbols can be replaced by the same letter.
	NOTE! The search can be a very resource-consuming operation. It is recommended to search for phrases (without spaces) rather then for separate words.

\tIf you are logged in, you can check whether your solution is correct or not. To do that, click %1$s on the sliding menu. If you become the first to solve the cipher, you get points as a reward. The number of points you get depends on the difficulty of the cipher.
Saving result as an image
\tYou can save the created image by clicking %1$s in the sliding menu.\n\tImages are stored in the \"%2$s/%3$s\" folder on the memory card.

You can create your own cipher and find ciphers created by other people on the %1$s. To enter it, click %2$s in the sliding menu.
	On the %1$s you can view ciphers sorted by date, popularity or reward. The popularity is determined by the number of people that have imported the cipher to solve it. The reward is the number of points you get if you solve the cipher.
There is following information available for each cipher: 
 - Reward / Difficulty. Reward is the number of points that is given for solving the cipher. Difficulty determines how difficult the cipher is. The first solver get the maximum number of points that equals to the cipher difficulty. The second solver gets half the points as a reward and every next solver gets less and less points until the cipher is solved by the maximum number of people. 
 - Solved / Max solved. Shows how many people have already solved the cipher and the maximum number of people who can get points for solving it. The icon is green if you've already solved the cipher. 
 - How many people are solving the cipher. 
 - Who was the first to solve the cipher. 
Every cipher has also an avatar of its author. You can click it to view the author's profile. You can also see the profile of the person that was the first to solve the cipher by clicking their name.
To import a cipher, click %3$s. You can find and load imported ciphers in the %4$s section of the sliding menu on the main screen. To see more information about the cipher click on the cipher title on the top of the menu.
	If the cipher is solved by maximum number of people, you can see the solution by clicking the %5$s button.
Creating a cipher

If you are logged in, you can create a cipher. You can specify a title, a description and a plaintext to encrypt. The cipher will then be generated using random symbols from the Zodiac cryptogram. You can regenerate the cipher until you are satisfied with the result.
	Only English characters are considered in the plaintext and placed in the generated cryptogram. There are no requirements regarding the difficulty of the cipher, so it is totally up to you how difficult and adequate it is.
	You can see the calculated difficulty of the generated cipher. The difficulty of the cipher determines how many points will be given to the first solver as a reward. The author gets 3/10 of the points once the cipher is solved.
The difficulty D is calculated this way:
	D = S * MIN(S / P, 2), 
where S is the number of unique symbols in the cipher, P is the number of unique letters in the plaintext.
Logging in

\tTo be able to create a cipher or check your solution, you need to be logged in. You can create a new account or log in using existing one on the %1$s screen. The screen can be accessed from both the main screen and the %2$s screen.
Avatar

You can change your avatar on your profile screen. The avatar creating screen consists of a panel with face parts, a preview panel with the generated avatar and four sliders that determine the location and the scale of the chosen part of a face.
Created by Dmitry Akishin\nIcons by Icon8
About

Searching for multiple words can be a very resource-consuming operation and the search might be stopped due to memory issues. You should use this option when current symbol binding is rich enough. It is also recommended to search for phrases (without spaces) rather then for separate words.
Search parameters:\n%1$s - the results must not contradict the current substitution.\n%2$s - different ciphertext symbols can be replaced by the same plaintext letter.

The Homophonic Substitution cipher is a substitution cipher in which single plaintext letters can be replaced by any of several different ciphertext letters.\nThey are generally much more difficult to break than standard substitution ciphers.

The difficulty of the cipher determines how many points will be given to the first solver as a reward. The author gets 3/10 of the points once the cipher is solved.
The difficulty D is calculated this way:
	D = S * MIN(S / P, %1$.0f), 
where S is the number of unique symbols in the cipher, P is the number of unique letters in the plaintext.
